--On Tuesday, August 12, 2003 9:23 AM +0200 Yannick Loiseau 
<yloiseau@free=
.fr> wrote:
> Here, you're defining a generic behaviour for a container "su=
per-type".

No I am saying that HTTP imposes strict requirements on how you=
 interact 
with a container.  See the definition of POST in rfc2616.  See m=
y last 
reply to Roy.

> If this is all of Most, I'm ok with it.
> If I wel=
l understood, MoST is nothing more a set of
> rules/design-behaviour patter=
n/generic types/semantic ... call it how
> ever you like, build on top of R=
est, just as RDF or web calculous can be
> considered too. If this is the c=
ase, there is no debate at all!

MoST is REQUIRED by HTTP (RFC2616).  RDF a=
nd the web calculus are 
permitted.  ReST may be *incompatible* with HTTP (=
it is hard to tell).

> These are application level specificities, while Re=
st is
> communication/interaction level.

MoST addresses the same level as =
ReST.

> You can define a common way to express
> rules and restrictions of=
 your application, as you can define a generic
> container "super-type", wi=
th the corresponding behaviours, but I thing
> that is out of the scope of =
ReST...

HTTP completely specifies the meaning of HTTP methods with respect=
 to HTTP 
resources.  If you are defining different meanings for these meth=
ods you 
are violating HTTP.  MoST is just the observation that HTTP is goo=
d. 
Neither MoST nor HTTP says anything about the behavior of agents that 
=
interact with those resources.

-Alex-

> Le lu=
n 11/08/2003 =E0 20:07, Alex Jacobson a =E9crit :
>> --On Saturday, August =
09, 2003 11:08 AM +0200 Yannick Loiseau
>> <yloiseau@...> wrote:
>> >> =
So, if you let MoST constrain your system around its formats, you
>> >> wou=
ld have achieved a 1000% productivity increase.
>> >
>> > Ok, so give an ex=
ample.. I have to admit that i don't really
>> > understand. You have to de=
fine a format that is suitable for any kind
>> > of application. This look =
quite ambitious. You can use RDF to help the
>> > representation to be self=
 descriptive, but you still have to define (ou
>> > refine) and RDFS. From =
an other pov, your proposal looks like wsdl (as
>> > Bill? said).
>>
>> See=
 my comments on taking HTTP seriously in the other thread.
>> Earlier, you =
defined an inbox index format.  I am saying that is enough
>> to  define yo=
ur entire application from the client's perspective.
>>
>> If the server re=
turns an index in response to a GET without an Accept
>> header, the resour=
ce is an index and NOT a container.  That means the
>> semantics of POST  s=
hould be with respect to that index and not a
>> container.  In other words=
, if the resource IS an index, then POST means
>> add an entry to the index=
 and NOT add a message to a container; messages
>> must be stored somewhere=
 else a la DJ Bernstein.
>>
>> If the server returns a container in respons=
e to a GET without an Accept
>> header, the resource is a container and not=
 an index.  That means the
>> semantics of POST should be with respect to t=
he container and not an
>> index.  In other words, if the resource is a con=
tainer, then POST means
>> add a  message to the container and can at your =
option affect an index.
>> Messages  are stored in the container  a la SMTP=
.  Note, nothing
>> constrains the  server from providing an index in respo=
nse to a GET with
>> a an "Accept:  text/x-yannick-index", but that is real=
ly beside the
>> point.
